profile.name: Ander
profile.title: Remote Software Engineer | Leadership, Growth & Technical Strategy
profile.description:
I enjoy solving problems—kind of like the Wolf from Pulp Fiction. When something’s broken, I’m the guy who steps in, figures it out, and makes it work, no matter the challenge.

I'm currently deciding whether to focus more on management or return to a more technical role. Over time, I've naturally taken on more leadership roles—building teams, defining the technical vision, and setting strategy—but I still enjoy getting hands-on with technical tasks.

The balance between leadership and technical work has changed over time. Some days it’s 40/60, other times 0/100 or 20/80, depending on the company’s needs, the team's needs and the product. I see it as a strength—different situations require different levels of involvement.

I value flexibility, async communication, and remote work. I value results, not hours. Becoming a father has made these things even more important.

I enjoy working with people who value Agile, DevOps, or XP and where I can keep learning.

I've been into AI and remote work for years, even before they were popular. When it comes to AI, I’m ready to contribute in areas like management, operations, or a mix of both, helping drive strategy and impact.

I’m a product-driven software engineer ⚡, with experience across the entire product lifecycle.

✔ Generalist? Yes ☝—I handle everything from gathering requirements, brainstorming, and planning to architecture, coding, deployment, and monitoring. In short, the full product lifecycle.

✔ Specialist? Also ✌—I have deep expertise in Frontend, but I’m also comfortable with Backend, Cloud infrastructure, and CI/CD pipelines to make sure everything works smoothly.

After my time at Comalatech, I realized that what I truly needed at that moment was immediate leadership responsibilities and a more stable financial situation—especially given the personal changes I was going through (buying a house, expecting my first child). Plain Concepts had always been a company I deeply aligned with, as I had grown and learned a lot there before. When the opportunity arose to return in a role that offered both management responsibilities and better compensation, it felt like the right move for my career and personal circumstances.

💥 Key Takeaway: Returned to step into a management role, gain immediate leadership experience, and work in an environment where I had previously thrived and felt aligned with the company’s culture.

💥 About Comalatech (Now Part of Appfire)

A Canadian software company specializing in developing **collaboration tools within the Atlassian ecosystem**. They offer applications for **Confluence and Jira**, enhancing content creation, review, and publishing workflows for businesses. In 2022, Comalatech was acquired by Appfire, expanding their reach in the document management domain.

📄 Worked on **Comala Document Management (6,000+ installs on Atlassian Marketplace)**, contributing to **frontend and backend development** of cloud-based workflow automation tools.  

🧪 Designed and implemented **End-to-End (E2E) and unit testing strategies** for Cloud products, ensuring that the most critical features and workflows were rigorously tested for reliability and stability in mission-critical enterprise tools. 

🐞 **Investigated, analyzed, and resolved complex bugs** in **Node.js, Express.js, AWS, React.js, Redux** applications, improving product reliability.  

☁️ **Focused on Cloud-first challenges**, including Serverless architectures, distributed queues, and large-scale data migrations.  

👟 Conducted **mentorship & training sessions**, introducing **TypeScript, refactoring best practices, and test automation**.  

🗨️ Advocated for **async-first communication**, optimizing remote collaboration across Spain, Mexico, and Canada.

💥 Why a Short Tenure?

I expected to grow into a leadership role and improve my compensation over time, but my personal situation—buying a house, expecting my first child—demanded stability and immediate growth opportunities. While I valued the product-driven environment and user impact, The role had technical challenges, but I was used to a higher pace and complexity. Adjusting took time, and I sought more opportunities to push my limits.

💥 Key Takeaway: Gained experience in product culture, remote work, serverless architectures (AWS), and user-facing development. Despite my short tenure, it was a valuable learning experience, and leaving was a difficult decision.

💥 About Plain Concepts

**Global IT professional services company** founded in 2006, focused on creating innovative, sustainable, and responsible technological solutions. 💥 About Obytes

Obytes is a **technology consulting company** specializing in web, mobile, and cloud solutions. They **help startups and enterprises build scalable digital products**, offering services in product strategy, UX/UI design, development, and DevOps.

As fully **remote** Frontend Developer and **Independent Contractor** I work with people from all over the world (New York, Morocco, Kuwait, Sweden, Spain...).

However, I realized I was **too early in my career for such an independent role** —I needed to learn from others, collaborate closely, and grow before returning to this level of autonomy.

💥 Key Takeaway: First remote & contractor experience, first direct exposure to C-levels, first time with this level of autonomy.

💥 About The Lobby  

The Lobby was an **early-stage startup** backed by **$1.2M in seed funding**, aiming to democratize access to top finance jobs by connecting job seekers with finance professionals for **coaching, referrals, and career insights**.

I work on The Lobby as fully remote Frontend Developer Independent Contractor. The Lobby is a New York based company.

💥 Key Responsibilities & Achievements 💥

🤝 **Developed a career coaching and job referral platform**, connecting job seekers with finance professionals for **mock interviews, resume reviews, and career insights**.

👤 **Built the frontend and user interface**, enhancing user engagement and facilitating seamless interactions between candidates and industry insiders.

🔎 **Implemented server-side rendering (SSR)** to improve **SEO performance and initial load time**, optimizing discoverability.

🐍 **Integrated RESTful APIs built with Python (Django)** to manage user authentication, session handling, and profile data.

🚀 **Contributed to setting up CI/CD pipelines**, automating testing and deployments.

💥 Why a Short Tenure? 💥

This was my first remote, fully autonomous position and my first contractor experience. I worked directly with C-level executives and gained React.js experience in a startup environment. However, I realized I was **too early in my career for such an independent role** —I needed to learn from others, collaborate closely, and grow before returning to this level of autonomy.

💥 Key Takeaway: First remote & contractor experience, first direct exposure to C-levels, first time with this level of autonomy.

💥 About Jinn  

Jinn was a **London-based on-demand delivery startup** founded in 2014, offering customers the convenience of ordering from local restaurants and stores with delivery times averaging around **30 minutes**. At its peak, Jinn expanded operations to multiple UK cities and completed **over a million deliveries** for more than **100,000 customers**. Despite its initial success and **raising ~$19M in funding**, Jinn faced intense competition and ceased operations in October 2017.  

💥 Key Responsibilities & Achievements 💥

🛵 **Frontend Development**: Developed and maintained the frontend for Jinn, a Deliveroo/UberEats-like app, handling 50,000+ orders per month, 500+ drivers, and 500+ stores across London and other cities.

📈 **Performance Optimization**: **Collaborated with the Backend team** to ensure that **Frontend performance** was optimized alongside backend improvements, improving **UI responsiveness** under high traffic conditions.  

⌚ **Feature Development**: Helped design and implement **real-time order tracking** and **dynamic delivery ETAs**, enhancing the user experience.  

🧪 **Testing & Code Quality**: Wrote and improved **unit and integration tests**, strengthening frontend reliability and preventing regressions.  

👨‍👩‍👧‍👦 **Cross-Functional Collaboration**: Worked closely with **designers, backend engineers, and product teams** to create a **consistent and scalable UI** aligned with business goals.

💥 About Pictel

Pictel was a Spanish company and an **official Movistar distributor**. Established in 2006, it specialized in the sale of **mobile telephony products and services**, catering to both **individual and business clients**. With a network of **39 retail stores**, a dedicated business sales team, and a call center, Pictel ensured comprehensive customer support and service.

✅ **Custom Software Development**: Engineered bespoke applications to address unique business challenges.

🔎 **SEO Optimization**: Implemented strategies focusing on Web Performance Optimization (WPO), meta tags, and structural code enhancements to boost search engine rankings.
    
👟 **Training & Mentorship**: Conducted training sessions on Requirements Analysis and Web Development, fostering skill development within the team.
    
🤝 **Cross-Functional Coordination**: Worked closely with various departments, including design, marketing, and IT, to ensure cohesive project execution.

manfredSpecificData.desiredJobDescription:
I enjoy solving problems—kind of like the Wolf from Pulp Fiction. When something’s broken, I’m the guy who steps in, figures it out, and makes it work, no matter the challenge.

I'm currently deciding whether to focus more on management or return to a more technical role. Over time, I've naturally taken on more leadership roles—building teams, defining the technical vision, and setting strategy—but I still enjoy getting hands-on with technical tasks.

The balance between leadership and technical work has changed over time. Some days it’s 40/60, other times 0/100 or 20/80, depending on the company’s needs, the team's needs and the product. I see it as a strength—different situations require different levels of involvement.

I value flexibility, async communication, and remote work. I value results, not hours. Becoming a father has made these things even more important.

I enjoy working with people who value Agile, DevOps, or XP and where I can keep learning.

I've been into AI and remote work for years, even before they were popular. When it comes to AI, I’m ready to contribute in areas like management, operations, or a mix of both, helping drive strategy and impact.

I’m a product-driven software engineer ⚡, with experience across the entire product lifecycle.

✔ Generalist? Yes ☝—I handle everything from gathering requirements, brainstorming, and planning to architecture, coding, deployment, and monitoring. In short, the full product lifecycle.

✔ Specialist? Also ✌—I have deep expertise in Frontend, but I’m also comfortable with Backend, Cloud infrastructure, and CI/CD pipelines to make sure everything works smoothly.
manfredSpecificData.goodPractices:
I enjoy solving problems—kind of like Mr. Miyagi from Karate Kid. When something’s broken, I’m not here to overcomplicate things. I just give it a good "dar cera, pulir cera", get to work, and fix it.

I don’t believe in hiding behind complexity or buzzwords. In my approach, simplicity always wins. It's not about the latest framework or the newest trend—it's about what works, what’s clear, and what gets results. Pragmatism is key, but the real kind, not the one you read about in LinkedIn posts. I focus on delivering value, not just ticking boxes.

Here are some key principles I live by:

📌 **Testing Strategy & TDD**: I’ve built testing strategies, frameworks, and adapted TDD to meet the team’s maturity and project needs. But it's not just about coding tests—it’s about building a culture where testing and quality are everyone’s responsibility. No shortcuts.

🚀 **Engineering Leadership & Decision-Making**: I help teams make decisions that matter, balancing speed with long-term impact and always keeping the cost-to-value ratio in mind. It's about delivering features quickly, getting real user feedback early, and making sure the product keeps evolving based on that. Forget theory—let’s focus on what really works. I work with engineers on design patterns and clean code, but I prioritize progress over perfection. Iteration is key, and small, continuous steps get us closer to delivering real value.

🔄 **Agile & Continuous Delivery**: I focus on fast iterations, baby steps that deliver value early and often. With each release, we gather feedback quickly from the users to steer the next iteration. This feedback loop allows us to adjust course quickly, making sure we stay aligned with what the customer really needs. It’s about testing and refining, not waiting for the “perfect” solution.

🛠 **Simplicity as a Core Engineering Principle**: KISS and YAGNI aren’t just buzzwords for me—they’re the way I work. Solutions need to be lightweight, maintainable, and easy to evolve. I avoid overengineering both in code and in process, because we all know how that turns into a mess down the line. Keep it simple, keep it moving.

⚡ **Refactoring & Technical Debt Management**: Whether it’s a greenfield or legacy codebase, I’ve led refactoring initiatives.. I’ve trained teams to identify and address technical debt—not because it's trendy, but because it’s essential for sustainable growth. We build systems that are practical, effective, and that can evolve without falling apart.

🧩 **Contextual Leadership & Adaptability**: Leadership isn't a one-size-fits-all approach. Some engineers need mentoring, others need autonomy. I adjust based on the team and the situation, always aligning efforts with the product and business strategy. No one gets left behind, but we don’t waste time either.

In summary, I focus on results—real ones. I balance technical expertise with leadership, staying committed to simplicity as the foundation of everything I do. I build maintainable software, while ensuring that teams work efficiently, deliver value quickly, and always improve.
